meanings.sent1: The royal mint will recoin the old currency.
meanings.sent2: The government decided to recoin the outdated coins.
meanings.sent3: The magical elf can recoin any metal into shiny new coins.
meanings.sent4: The blacksmith's skill seemed to recoin metal into gold.
meanings.sent5: The ancient king could recoin metal with a touch of his hand.

meanings.definition: To give new value or currency to something.
meanings.sent1: The artist's work can recoin ordinary objects into valuable art pieces.
meanings.sent2: The economic policy aims to recoin the struggling currency.
meanings.sent3: The fairy godmother can recoin pumpkins into golden carriages.
meanings.sent4: Her smile seemed to recoin the dreary day into a bright one.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's encouragement can recoin a student's self-worth.

meanings.definition: To make a new decision or judgment about something.
meanings.sent1: After careful consideration, she decided to recoin her career path.
meanings.sent2: The judge had to recoin his ruling based on new evidence.
meanings.sent3: The weatherman can recoin his forecast if the clouds suddenly disappear.
meanings.sent4: Her perspective seemed to recoin the situation, making it clearer.
meanings.sent5: The detective had to recoin his suspect list after finding a crucial clue.
